notes.comment: While the train and validation sets are still regime specific, they include transition phases to learn regime shifts

episodes.name: Dot-com bust
episodes.description: Bursting of the late-1990s internet stock bubble after years of speculative IPOs and easy capital. Tightening financial conditions and a 2001 recession, compounded by the 9/11 shock, drove multi-year declines centered in tech.

episodes.name: Post-bust base
episodes.description: Hesitant stabilization after heavy selling. Choppy, range-bound price action as markets gauged whether the worst was over.

episodes.name: Credit and housing expansion
episodes.description: Recovery supported by low rates and ample liquidity, strong credit growth, housing boom, and rising corporate earnings. Financials benefited from mortgage origination and securitization, which sowed later systemic risk.

episodes.name: Global Financial Crisis
episodes.description: Subprime defaults and collapsing mortgage-backed securities triggered institutional failures, a credit freeze, and a deep recession until extraordinary policy support began to stabilize conditions.

episodes.name: Post-GFC recovery
episodes.description: Near-zero rates and successive rounds of quantitative easing supported risk assets while profits recovered. Notable shocks included the May 2010 flash crash and the 2011 U.S. credit-rating downgrade during Europe’s debt crisis, but the broader trend was upward.

episodes.name: QE exit and global growth scare
episodes.description: Consolidation as the Fed ended QE3 and prepared for hikes. A major oil price collapse hit energy earnings, China’s 2015 yuan devaluation and growth concerns spurred volatility, and Brexit uncertainty added to risk.

episodes.name: Policy-fueled expansion
episodes.description: Rally on expectations of tax cuts, deregulation, and solid earnings. Corporate tax reform in 2017 reduced the statutory rate and supported profits. A near-bear correction occurred in Q4 2018 amid Fed tightening and U.S–China trade tensions, followed by a 2019 rebound as the Fed pivoted.

episodes.name: Mixed: COVID shock, rebound, inflation tightening
episodes.description: Includes the Feb–Mar 2020 COVID crash and extraordinary monetary support, the rapid post-COVID bull, then the inflation and aggressive Fed-hike period that produced a sideways phase roughly from early 2022 to April 2023, followed by recovery.
